marketing is not nearly as complex as private sector marketing for a variety of reasons, but the principles in marketing, advertising and selling are the same. In this article, we’re going to look at just some of those similarities.
One common misconception about marketing is that advertising and promotion are the most important components of marketing, but the most important component is public relations. The creation and maintenance of good will, both in the media and on the public’s general mind, is a difficult element to control or manipulate.
The US Federal Aviation Administration is a good example of good marketing, as are the state Department of Transportation offices. In the government, as in private business, if the public is not on the right side of the agency, the agency is not moving forward with implementing new programs. Public Relations promotes and sells the brand of the agency and its programs, and is considered one part of the marketing department; also in private industry.

the WHO, has now upgraded processed meat to “Group 1” – the most dangerous category in their classification system.
It follows the classification of alcohol, asbestos, tobacco and ultraviolet radiation.
‘Cause of cancer’
“Red meat,” the report concluded, “probably being in Group 3.”
It said processed meat, such as sausages and bacon, contained N-nitroso compounds and polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons which are cancer-causing.
“These are compounds that form during the preparation of meat that are found to increase cancer risk in animals,” says Peter Craighead from QUT’s School of Public Health.
“Their correction to Group 1 is probably appropriate. However, when communicating these changes it is important that processing the meat is not ignored; the important take-away is that it is the cooking oils, additives, and preservatives that are the culprit.”
That said, the promotion of processed meat to Group 1 is not really all that surprising, given it is only

Failure in the weeks ahead to reach a compromise on raising the nation's $14.3 trillion debt ceiling could call into question the United States' ability to pay its bills and spur a replay of the debt standoff that characterized early 2011. The Treasury estimates that Congress must reach agreement on raising the debt limit by mid-May to avoid running out of money in mid-July.
Meeting on Super Bowl Sunday in Arizona, Lew sought to reassure the world of the United States' economic primacy and its intent to keep focused on getting the U.S. economy back on track. Speaking of the past debt battle, he acknowledged that "in the beginning, it was clear that Congress could not walk away from the ability to pay the national debt. But this sort of drama still happens."

of diarrhea. These helpful foods help maintain fluid and electrolyte balance.
Often people with diarrhea choose to alter their diet considerably. In some cases it is appropriate to restrict some foods, especially those containing caffeine or alcohol. Still, the body needs fluids and nutrients.
When a person has diarrhea, one must ensure that he or she drinks adequate amounts of water, or other clear liquids, to replace the water lost in diarrhea. Foods with high water content include apple juice and chicken noodle soup. Another favorite is the humble bottle of Pedia-Lyte, the most frequently recommended oral rehydration fluids.
Unsaturated and monounsaturated fats are healthy fats, which may help moderate diarrhea. Olive oil can be added to chicken or fish in broth or sauce. Other fats may be fried or cooked flax, sunflower, almond, walnut, peanuts and avocados.
Other strong foods that can help a person manage his or her diarrhea are breads, pastas, potatoes and whole grain rice.

The contracts, worth $99.8 million, the largest boost to Boeing since November 2011, was on a modest scale for the UAE, the world’s ninth largest arms customer in the past few years.
Even so, it would give the UAE a small inventory of the UH-60V – with internal transport modifications including external tanks, hard points and additional rocket launchers – which has been touted as an operational upgrade.
It has yet to win orders from US military services, including the Marine Corps, which bought an older upgrade of the Black Hawk.

’ recent repudiation of the administration’s spending and taxing agenda, on Capitol Hill and at the ballot box. Speaking before a huge, bipartisan audience, the president cast the argument on Capitol Hill as one between him and middle-class priorities, on the one hand, and scheming, obstructionist Republicans on the other.
“They’ve made it clear that they work best when Congress is not in session,” Obama said.
But he also gave Democrats everywhere an option: “And if a Republican majority in Congress blocks me from meeting my responsibilities to the American people, I will act on my own,” he said. “And I will exercise the constitutional authority granted to me to move this government forward.”
He offered no timetable. It was less an ultimatum to Capitol Hill than it was a reminder to fearful lawmakers that there is a president with political capital to burn, who is going to reup his campaign activity in hard-fought states this fall.
Obama’s challenge now is political. Some Democrats — badly

road with!!! (pronounced Chk Chk Chk), Bristol Wright said. And while his touring partner isn't a real DJ, Wright was still honored to get the call.
Wright told MTV News that when his friend Barker sought him out for the dates, he was more than happy to shut off his computer and pick up his equipment.
"I was home racking up the techno tracks, and he called me and was like, 'Do you want to do some dates with us? We're doing some clubs,' " Wright said. " 'I don't know if you know about this band, but we're going to go around the country.' "
When the offer came in, Wright was more than flattered — considering he'd never actually worked with Barker before even though the pair had spoken many times. But when the timing of the tour came up, Wright couldn't turn down the chance to work with one of his dear friends.
"You're definitely dating yourself," the comedian laughed.

This year, it moved to Old Fort neighborhood park, where Dewey Road ends in Southside at 332 Etta St.
The Iungerichs were joined by nearly 20 more sculptors including 15-year-old Beijing, China exchange student, Summer Wang. Some of the sculptors camp out at the park maybe six days in a row, carving under lights late into the night.
The artists bring ice out of the river using a tank and a hose, Iungerich explained.
While adding rock salt to the river water makes ice sculptures unstable, she usually adds peroxide and a surfactant.

it is the only industrialised country whose maternal mortality rate is not falling – indeed, it is getting worse – and is heading for a rate similar to that of the developing world, is an exceedingly depressing reality.
I’m not keen on depression, but even more than usual the news on maternal mortality has filled me with despair. In the first place I mourn the 4,000 or so women in the U.S. who live out (or not) their lives every year after being injured in childbirth. It’s not as though their lives have enormous intrinsic value; my own mother managed a number of pregnancies in the U. Now she somehow wheeled and dealed her way into living past ninety-five in an America inherently blind, deaf and dumb to the possibility that anyone older than her could conceivably – even theoretically – be interesting. But still…is it right that women should die in childbed any more than housewives should die in dishwater or so many others die in sneakers? Despite

Public employee unions had pointed to the incoming Democratic majority in the House as a check on many of the administration's most controversial policy plans this term, but Monday’s order to the Office of Management and Budget shows that suspension of the Federal Employee Pay Table (FEPT) and revisions to federal employee retirement programs should still be seen as a possibility moving forward.
"The rulings today, which affect all federal employees, are just the latest attack by the Trump administration, trying to make union workers at agencies like NASA more at risk through delaying protection due to them under retirement rules," National Treasury Employees Union President Tony Reardon said via Twitter. "We have always said federal workers deserve a fair and meaningful compensation package, and we will continue to fight these harmful and disruptive moves.”

put Carolina away on a day that included the jarring end to a career for wide receiver Steve Smith.
Carolina (3-3) lost to Seattle (6-1) for the second straight season. This time it was in the suddenly souped-up Superdome, home of the NFL championship game.
Smith, the team�s all-time receptions leader, hurt his Achilles tendon against the New Orleans Saints in September and had surgery. In a comeback that has eclipsed every professional athlete�s return to health, Smith tried to step up just 16 days after having surgery -- using a bulky cast and protective boot for support.
But it became unsafe to continue, and Smith came off the field. He said he was unsure if he could ever play again.

.37 billion, excluding revenue from its Cole Haan and Umbro businesses, whose results were not included in the company’s previous quarter.
See also: Nike sees biggest rise in lead share ever
Sales from stores open more than a year in North America, where Nike gets about 49 percent of sales, climbed 9 percent in the quarter, paced by gains in women’s running, football and basketball. Sales grew 6 percent in Western Europe and 12 percent in Greater China, while Asia Pacific sales were flat.
“Nike did pretty well in North America for their first half (of the year) as they benefited from the running boom, sportswear interest and also from consumers buying last season’s shoes which temporarily lifted their sales,” Edison Investment Research analyst Neil Saunders said in a note.
Analysts had predicted an average profit of $1.16 per share and a revenue rise of 8 percent to $6.33 billion. Nike fell 2.8 percent to $50.

brücken. It's believed the windows were shattered by bullets fired from a nearby road.
A railway worker, who didn't want to be named, told dpa news agency that he believes the bullets hit the train, as the area around the window, several centimetres in diameter, was charred.

the home fire at 2:50 a.m., said Juan Bonilla, a spokesman for the Chicago Fire Department.
Fire officials said the home had no to no smoke detectors and all four members of the family were on different floors when the fire alarm went off.
The boy’s parents were in the hallway and were able to evacuate the children, Bonilla said.
His older sister, 12, was able to escape, while his younger brother, 17 months, was able to escape down the stairs.
“The father saw the little guy and grabbed him by the leg and pulled him out the door,” Bonilla said. “It was an impressive rescue.”

“We are keeping in our minds and hearts the family that is dealing with this tragedy,” said Fire Commissioner Ron Deveraux.

GPS, which combines signals from a network of navigation satellites with receivers mounted in or near vehicles, is used for automobile navigation systems today. Open networks for public use are taking over from proprietary systems of telecommunications firms.
Automobile traffic data would be a welcome bonus but much more exciting is the idea of the locations of people.
Two years ago GPS receiving chips costing up to $30 added up to multibillion dollar expenditure at a time when mobile phones were reaching nearly every adult on the planet.
Today there are many other low-powered chips, including some less than $2 that provide relatively accurate positioning - enough to know roughly which city or even which country you are in - without a GPS receiver, and without even calling on a cell phone's network.

In 1982, the Madison group at University of Wisconsin-Madison (Materials Science Department) began running the largest and greatest neutrino detector in the world. They were hoping to use this device, called a detector, to help determine the force of the hypothetical particles called massive fermions. Surprisingly enough, the detector did much more than that and gave a major outline where neutrinos come from in our universe. MadAsJoe (originally abbreviated for " Material Science Department's Advanced Scintillator Experiment ") was operated for four years at Fermi National Accelerator Laboratory (Fermilab), outside Chicago. It was run by Wisconsin Physicians and Academics (W.P.A.) of the United States of America.

Marketers are employed in the public sector as well as the private sector.
Most people think of marketing as a strictly private sector activity, but the reality is people with sales and marketing backgrounds are hired by government agencies in a number of capacities. Government marketing is not nearly as complex as private sector marketing for a variety of reasons, but the principles in marketing, advertising and selling are the same. In this article, we’re going to look at just some of those similarities.
One common misconception about marketing is that advertising and promotion are the most important components of marketing, but the most important component is public relations. The creation and maintenance of good will, both in the media and on the public’s general mind, is a difficult element to control or manipulate.
The US Federal Aviation Administration is a good example of good marketing, as are the state Department of Transportation offices. In the government, as in private business, if the public is not on the right side of the agency, the agency is not moving forward with implementing new programs. Public Relations promotes and sells the brand of the agency and its programs, and is considered one part of the marketing department; also in private industry.

An eagerly awaited report from the World Health Organization (WHO) states that processed meats such as bacon and sausages cause cancer, and red meat likely does so too.
The France-based International Agency for Research on Cancer (IARC), part of the WHO, has now upgraded processed meat to “Group 1” – the most dangerous category in their classification system.
It follows the classification of alcohol, asbestos, tobacco and ultraviolet radiation.
‘Cause of cancer’
“Red meat,” the report concluded, “probably being in Group 3.”
It said processed meat, such as sausages and bacon, contained N-nitroso compounds and polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons which are cancer-causing.
“These are compounds that form during the preparation of meat that are found to increase cancer risk in animals,” says Peter Craighead from QUT’s School of Public Health.
“Their correction to Group 1 is probably appropriate. However, when communicating these changes it is important that processing the meat is not ignored; the important take-away is that it is the cooking oils, additives, and preservatives that are the culprit.”

WASHINGTON (Reuters) - U.S. Treasury Secretary Jack Lew on Sunday warned Congress against manufacturing a crisis over federal spending in the months ahead, as looming deadlines set the stage for a repeat of the political deadlock which two years ago triggered worldwide financial market jitters.
Failure in the weeks ahead to reach a compromise on raising the nation's $14.3 trillion debt ceiling could call into question the United States' ability to pay its bills and spur a replay of the debt standoff that characterized early 2011. The Treasury estimates that Congress must reach agreement on raising the debt limit by mid-May to avoid running out of money in mid-July.
Meeting on Super Bowl Sunday in Arizona, Lew sought to reassure the world of the United States' economic primacy and its intent to keep focused on getting the U.S. economy back on track. Speaking of the past debt battle, he acknowledged that "in the beginning, it was clear that Congress could not walk away from the ability to pay the national debt. But this sort of drama still happens."

NEW YORK — Television retailer QVC has made aggressive plans to keep shoppers watching — instead of mall-hopping — on Black Friday, an event it has traditionally ignored.
The leading network for TV shoppers promises special deals and a healthy dose of new items, including $2,799 DKNY shoes, $1,499 Versace gold-tone watches and up to 85% off clothing and jewelry. Other premiere items include an Annie Leibovitz Digital Signature Edition photo book from Time Inc., free with the purchase of a traditional print version.
For this first-ever QVC Black Friday, the network has switched up its programming strategy. Longtime star Jane Tricomi, with more than 13 years on the air, is set to join a younger cast of shopping hosts. Christie Brinkley will be handling fashion content, while Kristin Chenoweth and Leslie Bibb will present specials.
Overall, QVC plans to promote 50 new items during the holiday programming. It expects 5 percent of its inventory in categories like jewelry, rings and watches will be new. That's the highest percentage in at least a decade, said Charles Jerger, the network's senior vice president of product development.

Occasional diarrhea is a common occurrence. Most people will experience an episode of diarrhea at least once or twice a year that will disappear in a couple of days.
Luckily, there are many foods to eat that may help a person reduce the symptoms of diarrhea. These helpful foods help maintain fluid and electrolyte balance.
Often people with diarrhea choose to alter their diet considerably. In some cases it is appropriate to restrict some foods, especially those containing caffeine or alcohol. Still, the body needs fluids and nutrients.
When a person has diarrhea, one must ensure that he or she drinks adequate amounts of water, or other clear liquids, to replace the water lost in diarrhea. Foods with high water content include apple juice and chicken noodle soup. Another favorite is the humble bottle of Pedia-Lyte, the most frequently recommended oral rehydration fluids.
Unsaturated and monounsaturated fats are healthy fats, which may help moderate diarrhea. Olive oil can be added to chicken or fish in broth or sauce. Other fats may be fried or cooked flax, sunflower, almond, walnut, peanuts and avocados.
Other strong foods that can help a person manage his or her diarrhea are breads, pastas, potatoes and whole grain rice.

Record low and negative interest rates in developed economies are fueling a ravenous search for yield that is forcing pension funds and other conservative institutional investors out of their comfort zones and into risky emerging markets, according to fund managers and analysts.
The reason for this “yield-composting,” where investors comb the world for the best yields, is the most risky sources at the best price. In the grand scheme of things, the worse the housing bubble in the U.S., the great the farmland bubble in Canada or the terror in the Ukraine. All roads lead to 12,000 bpd of oil and 23% decline in global energy prices. If it is worth it, all these risks can be managed – diversified global is here to stay.
Until yesterday when Saudi Arabia led a major OPEC production cut, demand uncertainty and a global economic meltdown came to the fore: in effect, demand-supply balance will kicked. And OPEC is losing a very signficant chunk of its bargaining lever that it had built up in the eyes of investors – best yield for nothing has just been taken off the table now.

Two UAE orders for military helicopters and guided bombs capped a remarkable year for procurement in which the Emirates became the largest foreign purchaser of US defence equipment, a Pentagon agency said.
The UAE, which has peacekeepers in Afghanistan, awarded Sikorksy Aircraft contracts to convert two Sikorksy UH-60M Black Hawks into two future heavy lift UH-60V helicopters, according to the list of $21.4 billion in major end use transactions with more than $500 million each by the Defense Security Cooperation Agency (DSCA) released overnight.
The contracts, worth $99.8 million, the largest boost to Boeing since November 2011, was on a modest scale for the UAE, the world’s ninth largest arms customer in the past few years.
Even so, it would give the UAE a small inventory of the UH-60V – with internal transport modifications including external tanks, hard points and additional rocket launchers – which has been touted as an operational upgrade.
It has yet to win orders from US military services, including the Marine Corps, which bought an older upgrade of the Black Hawk.

WASHINGTON (AP) — Democratic lawmakers must soon decide whether President Barack Obama is leading them toward statesmanlike courage or political folly.
Obama used his first State of the Union speech Wednesday to push nervous Democrats to forge ahead on health care, despite voters’ recent repudiation of the administration’s spending and taxing agenda, on Capitol Hill and at the ballot box. Speaking before a huge, bipartisan audience, the president cast the argument on Capitol Hill as one between him and middle-class priorities, on the one hand, and scheming, obstructionist Republicans on the other.
“They’ve made it clear that they work best when Congress is not in session,” Obama said.
But he also gave Democrats everywhere an option: “And if a Republican majority in Congress blocks me from meeting my responsibilities to the American people, I will act on my own,” he said. “And I will exercise the constitutional authority granted to me to move this government forward.”
He offered no timetable. It was less an ultimatum to Capitol Hill than it was a reminder to fearful lawmakers that there is a president with political capital to burn, who is going to reup his campaign activity in hard-fought states this fall.

Sponsored by Sen. Tom Carper (D-Del.), the Diesel Emissions Reduction Act (DERA) of 2019 would reauthorize the program at the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency through 2024 to assist firms with rebuilding and repowering existing medium and heavy-duty trucks and buses through rebates.
DERA also aims to reduce greenhouse gas emissions by 250,000 tons annually, saving 623 million gallons of fuel through 2024, the group noted. DERA also requires that all trucks resetting the state of the truck are repowered to reduce smog-forming emissions by 80% and reduce particulate matter emissions by 90%. According to this report from the North America’s Building Trades Union, the 25,000 tractor trailer drivers in the union save about $200 million in fuel and maintenance costs annually, and using newer technology to improve fuel efficiency saves $3.5 billion in fuel and maintenance costs annually.
What’s more, participating facilities have the flexibility to tailor construction plans to meet their unique needs, including in-plant demonstration programs, which allow fleets to evaluate repowered trucks in their own operations using everyday cargo movements.

'When Travis hollered, I was definitely flattered,' Kanye West's DJ says of getting the drummer's call.
It's been nearly a year since Travis Barker performed with a DJ, but now, he's getting ready to hit the road with!!! (pronounced Chk Chk Chk), Bristol Wright said. And while his touring partner isn't a real DJ, Wright was still honored to get the call.
Wright told MTV News that when his friend Barker sought him out for the dates, he was more than happy to shut off his computer and pick up his equipment.
"I was home racking up the techno tracks, and he called me and was like, 'Do you want to do some dates with us? We're doing some clubs,' " Wright said. " 'I don't know if you know about this band, but we're going to go around the country.' "
When the offer came in, Wright was more than flattered — considering he'd never actually worked with Barker before even though the pair had spoken many times. But when the timing of the tour came up, Wright couldn't turn down the chance to work with one of his dear friends.
"You're definitely dating yourself," the comedian laughed.

You cannot overestimate the mood of paranoia, hilarity and madness that pervades Westminster. Normal looking MPs seem to have messages branded on their foreheads: "tennis court repairs", "wife's tampons", like Hawthorne's scarlet letter. Lord Cropthorne would never have seen himself doing anything like it, but laboured under a mountain of ridiculously expensive BOUGHT forms from his department. It's his only hope of luring that junior finance minister and his wife out of the Cinema Muséum this weekend; toying with the Faculty chopping block outside.
Or even gentler than that; just being a dinosaur and getting disillusioned, either because you're losing an election, simply feel you've seen too many people kicked out and hope to make it in time to see your pay increased, or both.
Never underestimate the HoC's genuine desire, when it comes to any parliamentary perk or perk-rapist, for a revanche.
Of always having the wrong wallpaper.
It fancy at home.
Or your Hamlet rewriting projects.
There's even those not-stupid-so-often MP who just want to stop the dreadful behaviour... without feathering their own nest in the process, that's the challenge.
Labels: angling

After competing many times, local artist Ann Iungerich and her husband, David, decided to share some lessons learned Saturday in an ice-sculpting workshop.
The concept was more sculptors might make for a better competition.
"We've done them before. It's a great event, but it would be even more fun if more people had better exerted their artistry," Iungerich said.
The Worthington Park District, in partnership with the surrounding communities, has been holding the annual Art in Ice shows for about 20 years.
This year, it moved to Old Fort neighborhood park, where Dewey Road ends in Southside at 332 Etta St.
The Iungerichs were joined by nearly 20 more sculptors including 15-year-old Beijing, China exchange student, Summer Wang. Some of the sculptors camp out at the park maybe six days in a row, carving under lights late into the night.
The artists bring ice out of the river using a tank and a hose, Iungerich explained.
While adding rock salt to the river water makes ice sculptures unstable, she usually adds peroxide and a surfactant.

Why are American women dying in childbirth?
Maternal mortality rates are falling in every industrialised nation - except for the United States.
The United States is not the first place that springs to mind when considering women dying in childbirth. So the fact that it is the only industrialised country whose maternal mortality rate is not falling – indeed, it is getting worse – and is heading for a rate similar to that of the developing world, is an exceedingly depressing reality.
I’m not keen on depression, but even more than usual the news on maternal mortality has filled me with despair. In the first place I mourn the 4,000 or so women in the U.S. who live out (or not) their lives every year after being injured in childbirth. It’s not as though their lives have enormous intrinsic value; my own mother managed a number of pregnancies in the U. Now she somehow wheeled and dealed her way into living past ninety-five in an America inherently blind, deaf and dumb to the possibility that anyone older than her could conceivably – even theoretically – be interesting. But still…is it right that women should die in childbed any more than housewives should die in dishwater or so many others die in sneakers? Despite

President Trump’s decision Monday to revive plans to freeze federal employee pay in 2020 and to institute a series of cuts to federal employee retirement programs was met with great consternation from stakeholder groups, although the ideas stand little chance of becoming reality.
Public employee unions had pointed to the incoming Democratic majority in the House as a check on many of the administration's most controversial policy plans this term, but Monday’s order to the Office of Management and Budget shows that suspension of the Federal Employee Pay Table (FEPT) and revisions to federal employee retirement programs should still be seen as a possibility moving forward.
"The rulings today, which affect all federal employees, are just the latest attack by the Trump administration, trying to make union workers at agencies like NASA more at risk through delaying protection due to them under retirement rules," National Treasury Employees Union President Tony Reardon said via Twitter. "We have always said federal workers deserve a fair and meaningful compensation package, and we will continue to fight these harmful and disruptive moves.”

CHARLOTTE (AP) � Russell Wilson and the Seattle Seahawks defense were too much for Cam Newton and the Carolina Panthers to overcome.
Wilson threw a 13-yard touchdown pass to Golden Tate with 35 seconds left in the third quarter to help put Carolina away on a day that included the jarring end to a career for wide receiver Steve Smith.
Carolina (3-3) lost to Seattle (6-1) for the second straight season. This time it was in the suddenly souped-up Superdome, home of the NFL championship game.
Smith, the team�s all-time receptions leader, hurt his Achilles tendon against the New Orleans Saints in September and had surgery. In a comeback that has eclipsed every professional athlete�s return to health, Smith tried to step up just 16 days after having surgery -- using a bulky cast and protective boot for support.
But it became unsafe to continue, and Smith came off the field. He said he was unsure if he could ever play again.

Nike Inc enjoyed big sales in gains in North America and Europe last quarter and benefited from fewer markdowns, helping the maker of sports clothes and shoes report a stronger-than-expected quarterly profit.
Total revenue rose 7.7 percent to $6.37 billion, excluding revenue from its Cole Haan and Umbro businesses, whose results were not included in the company’s previous quarter.
See also: Nike sees biggest rise in lead share ever
Sales from stores open more than a year in North America, where Nike gets about 49 percent of sales, climbed 9 percent in the quarter, paced by gains in women’s running, football and basketball. Sales grew 6 percent in Western Europe and 12 percent in Greater China, while Asia Pacific sales were flat.
“Nike did pretty well in North America for their first half (of the year) as they benefited from the running boom, sportswear interest and also from consumers buying last season’s shoes which temporarily lifted their sales,” Edison Investment Research analyst Neil Saunders said in a note.
Analysts had predicted an average profit of $1.16 per share and a revenue rise of 8 percent to $6.33 billion. Nike fell 2.8 percent to $50.

Passengers on an ICE travelling from Berlin to Saarbrücken were shocked after windows were shattered by what they believe were bullets.
Police are investigating after windows on the ICE high-speed train were shattered during the journey from the German capital to Saarbrücken. It's believed the windows were shattered by bullets fired from a nearby road.
A railway worker, who didn't want to be named, told dpa news agency that he believes the bullets hit the train, as the area around the window, several centimetres in diameter, was charred.
Nearby security footage has been found and provided to authorities, according to the conductor. "The on-board camera shows that a projectile had hit the train and bounced off," a spokesman for the railway operator Deutsche Bahn told dpa.
However the conductor of the train said it was his intention to remove security camera footage from the train, although this was thwarted when he lost his key to the room containing the footage shortly afterwards.
No one on board was injured in the incident, which the conductor said was about 50 kilometers north of the border between Baden-Württemberg and Hesse near the town of Schlüchtern. The train left Berlin at 2.44

WHEN predicting which planets beyond Earth could support life, astronomers usually follow the water. Exoplanets with rocky surfaces are declared habitable if they orbit far enough from their star to potentially host oceans.
But as our planetary collection grows, and telescopes advance to looking at shorter timescales, previous assumptions are proving to be naive. Earlier this month, astronomers discovered the first evidence for lakes of liquid water on an exoplanet. They observed the cloud-shrouded surface of Wasat b, a warm, temperate planet orbiting a bright star called K2-155, as they faded in and out. Such brightness changes, called transits, occur whenever an exoplanet passes in front of its star as seen from Earth. On dry planets, clouds are unlikely to affect the results, but high humidity could have affected K2-155f’s transits.
At a less wet planet with temperatures close to freezing, giant hail from evaporating clouds could alter the outcome of transit observations. Researchers already know that in the atmospheres of giant planets, clumps of ammonia ice can grow until they become too heavy and fall as hail. But, studies found most planets follow a trend from larger to smaller sizes for hailstones. Nothing has

The latest attacks in Barcelona and the seaside resort of Cambrils on Thursday has left at least 14 dead and 100 injured.

Mattel's Future: Happily Ever After?
Mattel has a plan for the rest of the year, but it seems to be playing a shorter game.
According to its most recent earnings release, Mattel (NASDAQ:MAT) seems to believe that its troubles are over. Segment performance, fixed costs, and segment margin will all improve during the rest of the year "driven by strong gross margin performance."
The problem with Mattel's projections, though, is that there's no indication as to why the company thinks its situation is going to improve. Most gardeners think of diascias as low-growing bedding plants suited to a summer container or the front of a sunny border.
However Diascia personata breaks the mould and produces stiff stems that grow 3ft tall. The substantial bright green stems form a rosette of long green leaves which sit all together at the base of the stems.

The Airline Vikings were playing for the state football championship in 1972 against Neville on a bad night for football in Monroe.
But after the team had gathered itself, head coach Jack Gray called his seniors together.
Gray, who coached the 2005 Neville team that won a state championship, didn't have the ideal situation when he arrived in Monroe to coach the Vikings. He brought with him Mike Swor, a Rougon graduate and former LSU player who was his assistant.
So Gray, as he prepared to move to Neville to take care of his wife, who was ill, sent a letter to Manasses Canestrini, the principal at a high school that hadn't made the state tournament since 1943.
Gray warned he was untested, and many of his assistants lacked experience. Could the school afford to hire him and Swor?
"It didn't bother me," Canestrini said of that letter. "Nor should it with any other principal. Let us say we made the wrong decision, what are the first people we'll blame? The coaches."

In the summer of 1993, I had one of those experiences that stay with me for the rest of my life.
I spent 10 weeks in Europe, beginning with a six-week law-school summer session at Charles University in Prague.
Prague, that atmospheric, storied, magnificent old city, still so under-the-radar that you could wander off into side streets and find charming little cafes, elegant boutiques and quiet centuries-old churches. It was still scratchy and resonant – not yet a tourist mecca – in that pre-Game-of-Thrones era.
I spent the first half of my time there taking classes from bohemian professors, whom – it still humbles me to look back – I thought I could match. Then, I traveled for a few weeks on my own. Somehow, I ended up in the Italian Dolomites in the middle of the night, alone, in a village premiering the 1991 film “The Silence of the Lambs.” So scared. Thrilled beyond imagination.

Ukraine has started siphoning off Russian gas bound for European customers. This follows the cutoff of gas supplies to Ukraine on January 1, after the two countries’ gas companies failed to agree on a price for 2009.
Gazprom, the main gas producer in Russia, claims that Russian prices are lower than those in Western Europe. It says Moscow charges $450 per 1,000 cubic meters. In view of the financial crisis in Ukraine, Gazprom was ready to pay Ukraine just over $55 for a cubic meter, much less than the roughly $250 Kiev had requested.
According to a recent World Bank report, average wage: in Ukraine is $84, in Russia $4400. The annual salary of the Prime Ministers of both countries is about 200 000 USD.
Russia overtook Saudi Arabia as the leading exporter of gas to European countries several years ago. In 2007 it supplied just over 24 percent of the continent’s imported gas. Nearly one third of this transit gas passed through Ukraine.

Finland faces heightened risks from links between radical Islam and terrorism, according to a fresh report by Finland’s security and intelligence police unit Supo. The unit points to the ongoing Syrian conflict as a source of the increased threat.
According to the Supo report, the scale of the most serious threat since the Sept. 11 attacks still remains below Finnish government’s previous assessments. The risk was nonetheless elevated over the previous threat assessment from 2014.
If countries in the region collapse and descend into chaos in the future, the security and intelligence police are projecting an intensification in militant groups. Supo assesses Finland’s recent NS&U decision to allow four Syrian civil society groups access to the country is a reason behind the elevated risk level.
“There was a smaller risk because of the terror organisational structures that the Islamic State constructed and it’s possible that Finland didn’t end up as a target. In the spring, the terror cells that had been in Finland left as the organisation crumbled,” said Rita Savela, the chief analyst of Supo in a press briefing on the new report.

GENEVA, Mar 18 2013 (IPS) - The current growth model is not sustainable. Neither the green economy nor alternative sources of energy can prevent global warming. Solutions will come from concerted actions at the local and national levels, the United Nations Conference on Trade and Development (UNCTAD), and an expert group in the field of sustainable development say.
The U.N.’s historic Rio+20 conference that was held last June in Brazil warned that unless world leaders agree on the implementation of a comprehensive plan to combat climate change, indications are that emissions will far surpass the limit set by the 2009 Copenhagen agreement.
This deadline prompted a push towards green economic practices that harness the synergies tied to sustainable development.
But in a special U. N. report entitled “Environmentally Sustainable Trade and Investment Policies (ESTIPs)”, UNCTAD puts a question mark to the role of foreign investments as a solution for both climate change and increased social sustainability.
The report was prepared for U. N. Secretary General Ban Ki-moon’s Commission on Sustainable Development (CSD), the body responsible for reviewing the sustainable development goals strengthened by Rio+20 to ensure they are compatible with the Millennium Development Goals (MDGs).

Donnelly Park is a peaceful park in the middle of town where some ducks have been known to stop by to stop by to spend the evening. Earlier this week, the park's manager found two ducks with two-foot zip ties around their heads that were swallowing the plastic.
“They've been going to warehouses, saying next door, and checking out the area and so far, they seem to be doing OK,” said Dana Walsh, the leader of the Turlock Area Franchisees.
Walsh thinks the plastic material could inhibit their breathing or throat. They could also not be able to open and shut their bills as easily.
Walsh needs to know immediately if you see the ducks around the warehouse. If you see one, you need contact her at 209-GUIDE-UPS or direct message her on Facebook. Walsh is determined to get these Ziploc ducks out of plastic prison and back to their happy nesting.

Natural Resources Minister Jim Carr endorsed an advisory council report Thursday that spells out an ambitious agenda for Canada’s energy market to meet the emissions reduction targets set under the Paris Climate Accord.
The report, “Innovation & Energy Strategy for Canada,” makes 19 recommendations — each aimed at making shifts of varying scale — to support Canada’s energy industry through what the advisory council sees as a “decade of transformation.” It also calls for creation of a $30-billion fund for low-carbon projects.
Stephen Heintz, president of the Rockefeller Foundation in New York, was among those who suggested business and Canada’s government can both green up their operations and realize profit.
The report was written by a panel that includes George Mobio, the CEO of clean tech company Travois Capital. Smartphones can play a very positive role as a new tool with ophthalmologists, shows a new study conducted by the Emory University.
Smartphones can be extensively used by ophthalmologists for viewing complex inner eye photos for diagnostic purpose. They can also help patients stay aware of changes in their symptoms in order to take essential preventative measures.
“Ophthalmologists have a significant need for portable, accessible mobile devices for communication and photographs,” said Babak Ehteshami, MD, chief of ophthalmology at Emory, Professor of Ophthalmology in the School of Medicine at Emory University in Atlanta, Georgia.
The study is published online in EyeNet, an online publication of the American Academy of Ophthalmology.
He added, “As mobility and the ability to view real-time photos become increasingly important in our everyday workflow, smartphones are rapidly emerging to fill this niche as an affordable alternative.”
In the absence of electronic medical records, smartphones can be as useful to physicians than a notebook.
“By providing an experience that is more robust than the unified communication of a traditional telephone, smartphones provide the real-time, in-person experience that is quintessential in medicine of any kind, and certainly great importance in ophthalmology”, said Dr.

Rezaian pleaded not guilty, his attorney Leila Ahsan told The Huffington Post. The 37-year-old was accused of espionage, propaganda against the establishment, tainted Moezan, communications with evidence, and conspiracy against national security.

California is lifting its drought emergency for most of the state after a winter of record rain and snowfall that followed a five-year dry spell.
Gov. Jerry Brown's office announced Friday that his executive order will lift the drought emergency in California, except for a portion of the state near Lake Oroville, the state’s second largest reservoir. Brown has blamed the past drought on climate change.
A few months earlier, Brown lifted the state’s drought emergency for his home county, the Sacramento area.
The Bureau of Reclamation’s California State Director David B. Bernhardt said the recent wet weather caused severe flooding and possible erosion on the Feather River. Oroville Dam is suspected of being responsible due to severe erosion issues and potential damage to the Lower Feather River.
The Corps of Engineer's Diablo Army Corps is responsible for overseeing the safety of the Oroville Dam. The state is finally in renewables in the hope that the recent wet wet weather has lessened the effects of global warming.

CHICAGO -- A three-year-old boy died after a fire swept through his South Side home Sunday, police said.
Firefighters arrived at the three-story building on the 6700 block of South Dorchester Avenue two minutes after receiving calls of the home fire at 2:50 a.m., said Juan Bonilla, a spokesman for the Chicago Fire Department.
Fire officials said the home had no to no smoke detectors and all four members of the family were on different floors when the fire alarm went off.
The boy’s parents were in the hallway and were able to evacuate the children, Bonilla said.
His older sister, 12, was able to escape, while his younger brother, 17 months, was able to escape down the stairs.
“The father saw the little guy and grabbed him by the leg and pulled him out the door,” Bonilla said. “It was an impressive rescue.”
Responding firefighters rushed the boy to the University of Chicago Medical Center, where he was pronounced dead at 3:57 a.m. He suffered a burn to 70 percent of his body, fire officials said.
“We are keeping in our minds and hearts the family that is dealing with this tragedy,” said Fire Commissioner Ron Deveraux.

CHICAGO–UAL Corp.'s United Airlines yesterday became the latest airline to begin charging $15 (U.S.) to check a single bag on domestic flights, matching the controversial fee launched in May by AMR Corp.'s American Airlines, its chief competitor.
United is now matching almost all the industry's actions to address a slump in revenue: a round of fee increases, reductions to pensions and compensation, and smaller fleets and lay-offs.
Existing United flyers who check fewer than five bags a year will be the biggest losers from the charge. They were already exempt from the check-in fee. For them, costs will rise from $25 to $40 each way, although it is not yet certain when the new fee will be charged to get first crack at prime seats.
United, the world's No. 2 carrier, will reduce its published fares by 3 per cent, the company said.
"We look at every (revenue-boosting) alternative. We'd like to keep the fare increases and the fees, as those are the two big buckets," said Glenn Pomerantz, a United spokesman, noting that in a weak economic climate, merchandise, in-flight sales and re-booking fees are limited.

HELENA – A state panel heard four hours of testimony Wednesday on bills relating to missing and murdered Indigenous women, an issue that proponents said affect all Montanans, but could have a profound impact on the Native American community.
House Bill 6 would create a commission to study patterns and industry best practices to prevent violent crimes in Indian country, create incentives for states to partner to address these issues, and implement data systems eliminating data discrepancies in handling crimes in Indian country to ensure American Indians are not over-policed or ignored.
Another proposal, House Bill 5 would establish a commission to study how the criminal justice system impacts missing and murdered Indigenous and tribal women. The commission would try to eliminate barriers posed to law enforcement and information sharing, as well as study the safety of primarily Native people, even outside of Native American tribal land, as well as to ensure all states have the ability to share information and governmental reports on the issue.
Another bill, House Bill 222, would support economic development in Indian country and Medicaid coverage would be expanded for pregnant tribal women not enrolled in fee-for-service Medicaid even outside of Native American land.

FMCG major Hindustan Unilever (HUL) on Thursday reported a 9 per cent increase in its net profit to Rs 1,444 crore for the December 2018 quarter on account of strong volume growth and improved margins.
New Delhi: FMCG major Hindustan Unilever (HUL) on Thursday reported a 9 per cent increase in its net profit to Rs 1,444 crore for the December 2018 quarter on account of strong volume growth and improved margins.
The company had posted a net profit of Rs 1,323 crore in the same quarter last fiscal, HUL said in a statement.
Quarterly revenue from operations grew at a rate of 5 per cent at Rs 10,420 crore, when compared to Rs 9,975 crore in same quarter last fiscal.
"We have delivered strong results in Q3, driven by robust volume growth and margin improvement. Our strong show in beverages and home care speaks volumes of the premiumisation drive we are on and our commitment to deliver long term sustainable profitable growth," HUL MD and CEO Sanjiv Mehta said.
He further said the company continues to face a challenging operating environment which remains impacted by larger macroeconomic headwinds

PARIS (Reuters) - Finding friends and meeting new ones could become even more important uses for global positioning chips than getting from A to B as the technology spreads to cellphones in coming years.
Combined with mobile Internet access, GPS (global positioning system) technology in the mobile phones of 10 billion consumers would give them something no computer network has been able to provide - a real-time, ground-level map of the whole world.
GPS, which combines signals from a network of navigation satellites with receivers mounted in or near vehicles, is used for automobile navigation systems today. Open networks for public use are taking over from proprietary systems of telecommunications firms.
Automobile traffic data would be a welcome bonus but much more exciting is the idea of the locations of people.
Two years ago GPS receiving chips costing up to $30 added up to multibillion dollar expenditure at a time when mobile phones were reaching nearly every adult on the planet.
Today there are many other low-powered chips, including some less than $2 that provide relatively accurate positioning - enough to know roughly which city or even which country you are in - without a GPS receiver, and without even calling on a cell phone's network.

A neutrino event, identifiable by the rings of Cerenkov radiation that show up along the photomultiplier tubes lining the detector walls, showcase the successful methodology of neutrino astronomy. This image shows multiple events.
Sometimes, the best-designed experiments blow up the scientific world. In 1982, the Madison group at University of Wisconsin-Madison (Materials Science Department) began running the largest and greatest neutrino detector in the world. They were hoping to use this device, called a detector, to help determine the force of the hypothetical particles called massive fermions. Surprisingly enough, the detector did much more than that and gave a major outline where neutrinos come from in our universe. MadAsJoe (originally abbreviated for " Material Science Department's Advanced Scintillator Experiment ") was operated for four years at Fermi National Accelerator Laboratory (Fermilab), outside Chicago. It was run by Wisconsin Physicians and Academics (W.P.A.) of the United States of America.
During the latter part of the 20th century, it became very clear that no existing experimental evidence completely cured the theory that neutrinos are massive. Therefore, the detectors that were built used Fermilab's proton accelerator, called Main Injector

In the run-up to December’s global climate change meeting, fissures are emerging between Canada and the United States, as President Obama reconciles an ambitious carbon-cutting vision with the need to boost domestic energy production and job creation.
In early October, the United States and Canada hosted a climate change meeting in Ottawa, with the stated goal of unifying around an international goal of reducing carbon emissions. In many ways, the meeting’s goals ranged from ambitious to simply unlikely to actually happen. But already, the U.S. and Canada are not seeing eye-to-eye on several crucial provisions. 
The Canadian position is that a workable climate deal could entitle large, soot-heavy countries that curtail their industrial pollution to pollute their remaining emissions into the atmosphere in perpetuity. Coal-rich Australia, one of the world’s largest per capita emitters, is in agreement.

"The whole idea of ZeeMee was that we were students like most college-bound students," said Brian Chen, one of the company's two co-founder. "We were approaching college, we were going through the traditional Harvard application process, we were applying to other traditional schools around the country, and we were just like most everyone else across the country. And what we saw in that process was that there really wasn't a place for students to be themselves and express who they really were."
It occurred to Chen and his co-founder Ravi Ithurraluri, that 60 percent of the admissions decision, as they say on Harvard's application, was left to a long form, 650-character essay. ZeeMee's concept was that students could use a ZeeMee web page to project more

agencies at the local, state and federal level all employ marketing professionals in areas including, but not limited to, public relations, property disposal, bond sales and purchasing.
Almost all major government agencies have their own public-relations staff, and in many cases it is a stand-alone department with a public relations or media director and several support staff. Government agency PR departments are responsible for producing news releases, holding press conferences, and generally promoting activities of the agency, such as tourism or encouraging new businesses to move into the area.
Government agencies are constantly buying supplies, equipment and other property and selling off old equipment and property. The departments tasked with disposing of this government property often hire individuals with a background in marketing. Their job is to assist the agency in coming up with creative ways to sell or otherwise dispose of obsolete government property.
Most government agencies have to follow complicated regulations for purchasing supplies and equipment. In many cases, agencies can only buy from certain suppliers or can only buy goods within specific price ranges. Agencies

the WHO, put processed meats on the top of their “things that cause cancer list”, grouping them alongside tobacco, asbestos and diesel fumes, for which there is “sufficient evidence” of cancer links.
Along the years, there have been many studies that linked processed and red meats with cancer (especially bowel cancer), but there were always some doubts floating about. Now, the 22-member panel analyzed animal experiments, studies of human diet and health, and cell mechanisms that could lead from these meats to cancer.
“These findings further support current public health recommendations to limit intake of meat,” Dr. Christopher Wild, who directs IARC, said in a statement.
The decision wasn’t unanimous though, and a “probably” still crept in to the report. Many studies show the links, both in populations of people and in tests that show how eating these foods can cause cancer, the International Agency for Research on Cancer (IARC) said in its report, released in the Lancet medical journal.

A debt ceiling showdown in August 2011 between Obama and congressional Republicans sparked wild stock market swings and cost the United States its top-tier AAA credit rating.
“We need to get the debt limit extended in a way that doesn’t create a crisis,” Lew said.
Republicans see the debt ceiling as the their best leverage in winning a deal with Obama that would cut federal government spending to lower the deficit.

of diarrhea. There are also some foods to avoid when dealing with a bout of diarrhea, and some additional home care tips to consider.
Anyone who is experiencing persistent diarrhea should see a doctor, as a person may become dehydrated over time.
Diarrhea is a bowel movement that is more liquid than solid or has a loose texture. It is a common problem and may occur a couple of times each year. Diarrhea will usually last no more than 3 days.
Soft, bland foods, such as toast, will help to absorb excess water and ease the symptoms of diarrhea.
People with chronic digestive conditions, such as irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) or Crohn's disease, may experience diarrhea more regularly.
A person's diet is crucial if they are experiencing diarrhea. Some foods might help relieve symptoms of diarrhea while eating other foods can make diarrhea worse.
While recovering from diarrhea, a person should eat bland, simple foods that are easy to digest and will help absorb some water from

Nevada's effective monopoly on sports betting ended last spring, when the Supreme Court ruled the ban should be lifted. Casinos in seven other states — Rhode Island, Delaware, Mississippi, New Jersey, Pennsylvania, West Virginia and New Mexico — now accept wagers on sports. The list is expected to grow by next year with numerous states considering bills.
And there's already a hitch that could slow bets: NASCAR this season has decided for the first time to strip drivers of victories if their cars are deemed illegal. There will be a roughly 90-minute inspection after the race and the winner will not be deemed official until the process is completed. Will fans really want to linger around the pay window another couple of hours just to cash in a ticket?
"The state's risk manager will delay any payout until NASCAR releases the official order of finish," Kirk said.

On Valentine’s Day 2007, Lynn Blake was embarking on a new job in Vail Village when she had a rude awakening. The 27-year-old suffered sudden cardiac arrest. Fortunately for her, someone trained in CPR stepped forward and kept her heart beating until emergency personnel arrived with a defibrillator. If someone dropped in front of you unconscious, with no notable pulse, would you know what to do? Some 325,000 people die every year of sudden cardiac arrest (SCA) in the United States. And, contrary to popular belief, it strikes people of all ages. “I did not know a thing about cardiac arrest. I didn’t know what it was,” Blake said. Now she knows firsthand about sudden cardiac arrest. two American women die of pregnancy-related causes every day may come as a surprise.
According to the World Bank, The US ranks 50th in maternal mortality globally - falling behind every other industrialised nation. A woman in the US is as likely to suffer a maternal death as a woman in sanctions-hit Iran, and four times as likely as a woman in Germany.
"It is a preventable health issue," said Amnesty International's Rachel Ward. "It isn't something that we're waiting for a cure for. We’re waiting for political will."
What's worse is that US maternal mortality rates may actually be on the rise. Eugene Declercq, of Boston University's School of Public Health, produced a short film named Birth by the numbers, discussing maternal mortality in the US. In a 2013 follow-up report, he noted how mortality rates in other industrialised nations had declined - but in the US, it increased by 30 percent in the first decade of the new millennium.

It’s not the food—the grub is OK, if not exactly slimming; it’s the gas generators powering the carts. Most food carts run off a diesel generator that’s designed to run only a few hours. Vendors run them for stretches of up to 14 hours, leading to a high output of greenhouse-gas emissions such as carbon monoxide, nitrous oxide, and particulate matter. You can see the smoke with the naked eye, but the hard facts are even more frightening: The research and consulting firm Energy Vision found that each cart produces the same amount of nitrous oxide as 186 cars on the road.

In its milestone report, “The Limits to Growth”, published in 1972, the Club of Rome warned that the human ecological footprint had grown dangerously quickly from 1900 to 1972. Shortly thereafter, the warning proved to be prophetic: by 1986 the human ecological footprint had overshot the carrying capacity of the Earth. At current production and consumption levels, we need 1.5 planets to survive; if everyone lived like a U.S. citizen, we would need five planets.
Land, water and biodiversity continue to decline. Global CO2 emissions are on the rise. The oceans are warming and the sea level is rising continuously. Forest cover has decreased by 300 million hectares since 1990.

The study was conducted among some 350 patients who reported issues like headaches, eyesight changes and similar vision problems in emergency rooms.
The study also included the inner-eye photos taken by the ER staff using an ocular camera.
Then the study team assessed the response of two ophthalmologists who viewed and rated the pictures on a desktop PC and did the same on an iPhone.
The results of the study, published in the Archives of Ophthalmology, show that the doctors found the iPhone images good or better than desktop images and rated them high.
While one ophthalmologist felt 53 pictures were of the same quality, he found 46 better on iPhone and just one was better on PC.
For the other ophthalmologist who participated in the study, 56 were of equal quality, while 42 were better on iPhone leaving only two better on PC.

many celebrated breakthroughs were initially met with scorn and ridicule. We've compiled 11 such world-famous ideas from the history of science and technology. The temptation, of course, is to include those ideas that were scorned and should have stayed scorned. The Star Wars prequels, say. But we're trying to run a classy operation here.
Heliocentrism Galileo Galilei, sometimes called the Father of Modern Science, was among the first and most famous to pay a price for his crazy scientific ideas. Galileo publicly promoted the Copernican concept of heliocentrism -- that the Earth revolves around the Sun -- back when the Church and even most fellow mathematicians held to geocentric model. Unfortunately, in 17th century Rome, such radical ideas were quite literally heresy. Galileo was forced to recant and spend the rest of his life under house arrest.

"If there was any threat modeling at all, it was really badly done," Gutmann, from the University of Auckland, New Zealand, said while giving a talk on Vista content protection. "Once the enemy is the user and not the attacker, standard security thinking falls apart."
Vista requires premium content like high-definition movies to be degraded in quality when sent to high-quality outputs, so users are seeing status codes that say "graphics OPM resolution too high." Gutmann calls this "probably the most bizarre status code ever."

Yet, every once in a while, the apparatus that you build might be sensitive to something else entirely. IBM on Tuesday announced a prepackaged and pretested cluster that is powered by Advanced Micro Devices Inc.s 64-bit Opteron processor.
IBM, of Armonk, N.Y., is combining its Opteron-based eServer 325 server—which targets scientific and technical computing users—with systems management software and storage devices to offer a bundled package that can run Linux and Windows operating systems.
The new offering, which will be available later this month or in early December, is part of IBMs eServer Cluster 1350, which also includes bundles based on the companys BladeCenter blade servers and two-processor x335 and x345 systems using Intel Corp.s 32-bit Xeon chips.
Clusters comprise multiple servers tied together to create a supercomputing environment for users. In a related move, IBM last week announced that it was teaming with Corning Inc., the U.S. Department of Energy and the National Nuclear Security Administration to develop high-speed, optically switched interconnects for supercomputers. Marketers are employed in the public sector as well as the private sector.
Most people think of marketing as a strictly private sector activity, but the reality is people with sales and marketing backgrounds are hired by government agencies in a number of capacities. Government agencies at the local, state and federal level all employ marketing professionals in areas including, but not limited to, public relations, property disposal, bond sales and purchasing.
Almost all major government agencies have their own public-relations staff, and in many cases it is a stand-alone department with a public relations or media director and several support staff. Government agency PR departments are responsible for producing news releases, holding press conferences, and generally promoting activities of the agency, such as tourism or encouraging new businesses to move into the area.
Government agencies are constantly buying supplies, equipment and other property and selling off old equipment and property. The departments tasked with disposing of this government property often hire individuals with a background in marketing. Their job is to assist the agency in coming up with creative ways to sell or otherwise dispose of obsolete government property.
Most government agencies have to follow complicated regulations for purchasing supplies and equipment. In many cases, agencies can only buy from certain suppliers or can only buy goods within specific price ranges. Agencies

MIDDLETOWN, NJ - The Middletown Township Public Library and the Township of Middletown are pleased to announce the appointment of Kim Rinaldi as Provisional Library Director, beginning on February 24, 2014. Ms. Rinaldi will earn a salary of $95,000.00 per year.
Ms. Rinaldi comes to the Middletown Township Public Library after having served as the Library Director of the Margaret E. Heggen Free Public Library in Washington Township, New Jersey. During her tenure in Washington Township, Ms. Rinaldi managed 26 employees and a $2.5 million annual budget. Ms. Rinaldi has also served as the Director of the Brielle Public Library and as a Senior Librarian at the Ocean County Library, Long Beach Island Branch in Surf City, New Jersey.
Ms. Rinaldi holds a Masters in Library and Information Science from Texas Women’s College and has extensive experience in library administration, budgeting and project management. Ms. Rinaldi is credited with outsourcing material cataloging and processing at the Margaret E. Heggan Free Public Library, reducing annual operating costs by $150,000.00. Ms. Rinaldi

An eagerly awaited report from the World Health Organization (WHO) states that processed meats such as bacon and sausages cause cancer, and red meat likely does so too.
The France-based International Agency for Research on Cancer (IARC), part of the WHO, put processed meats on the top of their “things that cause cancer list”, grouping them alongside tobacco, asbestos and diesel fumes, for which there is “sufficient evidence” of cancer links.
Along the years, there have been many studies that linked processed and red meats with cancer (especially bowel cancer), but there were always some doubts floating about. Now, the 22-member panel analyzed animal experiments, studies of human diet and health, and cell mechanisms that could lead from these meats to cancer.
“These findings further support current public health recommendations to limit intake of meat,” Dr. Christopher Wild, who directs IARC, said in a statement.
The decision wasn’t unanimous though, and a “probably” still crept in to the report. Many studies show the links, both in populations of people and in tests that show how eating these foods can cause cancer, the International Agency for Research on Cancer (IARC) said in its report, released in the Lancet medical journal.

WASHINGTON (Reuters) - U.S. Treasury Secretary Jack Lew on Sunday warned Congress against manufacturing a crisis over federal spending in the months ahead, as looming deadlines set the stage for a repeat of the political deadlock which two years ago triggered worldwide financial market turmoil.
In coming negotiations with Republicans, who control the House of Representatives, Democratic President Barack Obama will focus on ways to create economic gains for the middle class over spending cuts, Lew said.
“We have already done a lot of deficit reduction,” he said in an interview on NBC. Lew spoke on four TV talk shows, setting out Obama’s priorities ahead of an expected showdown this fall.
By early November, Congress must raise the legal limit on the country’s borrowing authority or risk an unprecedented default on the government’s debt.
A debt ceiling showdown in August 2011 between Obama and congressional Republicans sparked wild stock market swings and cost the United States its top-tier AAA credit rating.
“We need to get the debt limit extended in a way that doesn’t create a crisis,” Lew said.
Republicans see the debt ceiling as the their best leverage in winning a deal with Obama that would cut federal government spending to lower the deficit.

In case you missed it, the initials ICYMI stand for the first five words of this sentence. In the event you have, indeed, missed it (ITEYH, I, MI has not taken off yet for some reason), it’s most likely because you’re not on the Internet much, particularly Twitter, where individuals and outlets deploy it every few seconds to bring links to the attention of others who may not have seen them. The New York Times now even has a section at the bottom of its app called “In Case You Missed It” with articles from previous days.
While the extended phrase has been used in conversation for a long time, the shorthand betrays an anxiety central to the Internet epoch. There is simply too much readable, viewable and listenable data for anyone to stay abreast of, as a humor piece, “I’m All Caught Up!” by Nick Mickowski in McSweeney’s, playfully suggested.

NEW YORK — Television retailer QVC has made aggressive plans to keep shoppers watching — instead of mall-hopping — on Black Friday, an event it has traditionally ignored.
The leading network for TV shoppers promises special deals and a healthy dose of new items for sale starting on Thanksgiving night. Program host Dave James plans to stay awake for 28 hours of telethon-like coverage.
The day after Thanksgiving is traditionally the biggest shopping day of the year, called “Black Friday” because it’s key for many businesses to go in the black, or turn a profit. QVC, which competes with ShopNBC and the HSN home shopping network, has not wanted to get caught up in the frenzy and has always treated it as just another day for its sales pitches, said Doug Rose, the network’s vice president of programming and marketing.
“This year, and we’ve been planning on this for many months, we really expect to join the fray with the other retailers,” Rose said.

Occasional diarrhea is a common occurrence. Most people will experience an episode of diarrhea at least once or twice a year that will disappear in a couple of days.
Luckily, there are many foods to eat that may help a person reduce the symptoms of diarrhea. There are also some foods to avoid when dealing with a bout of diarrhea, and some additional home care tips to consider.
Anyone who is experiencing persistent diarrhea should see a doctor, as a person may become dehydrated over time.
Diarrhea is a bowel movement that is more liquid than solid or has a loose texture. It is a common problem and may occur a couple of times each year. Diarrhea will usually last no more than 3 days.
Soft, bland foods, such as toast, will help to absorb excess water and ease the symptoms of diarrhea.
People with chronic digestive conditions, such as irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) or Crohn's disease, may experience diarrhea more regularly.
A person's diet is crucial if they are experiencing diarrhea. Some foods might help relieve symptoms of diarrhea while eating other foods can make diarrhea worse.

Record low and negative interest rates in developed economies are fueling a ravenous search for yield that is forcing pension funds and other conservative institutional investors out of their comfort zones and into risky emerging markets, according to fund managers and analysts.
The reason for this has little to do with the attractiveness of EM investments. On the contrary, EM economic growth is at its lowest level since the 2008/09 financial crisis while the prospect of a U.S. monetary tightening creates the potential for financial turbulence.
The force propelling pension funds and insurance companies into unfamiliar EM investments is simple. If they stay at home, their investment returns are at risk of falling short of their liabilities.
"If you require, say, 5 percent a year in order to cover your insurance or pension liabilities, that is not available from developed market (debt) obviously," said Colm McDonagh, head of emerging market fixed income at Insight Investment.
Brett Diment, head of emerging market debt at Aberdeen Asset Management, also sees a diversification into EM debt by pension and insurance companies. "We are seeing a broader group of investors looking at the emerging market debt asset class, including some insurers and pension funds that have not looked before."
Much of this search for yield

Two UAE orders for military helicopters and guided bombs capped a remarkable year for procurement in which the Emirates became the largest foreign purchaser of US defence equipment, a Pentagon agency said.
The UAE, which has peacekeepers in Afghanistan, awarded Sikorksy Aircraft a US$171 million (Dh628m) contract for 14 UH-60 Black Hawk helicopters, which are used for tactical transport.
Separately, the US defence security co-operation agency, a unit of the Pentagon, said last week it had notified Congress of a potential sale of enhanced guided bomb units, parts, training and support to the UAE for about $290m.
The same agency said in November that in the last fiscal year the UAE became the largest foreign purchaser of US defence equipment with sales of $7.9bn, ahead of Afghanistan ($5.4bn), Saudi Arabia ($3.3bn) and Taiwan ($3.2bn).
The spending included orders for munitions for the UAE’s F-16 fighter jets as well as a new Patriot defensive missile system and a fleet of corvettes for the navy.
The UAE purchases have been fuelled by a quadrupling of oil prices in the past decade and by continuing regional tensions, including those involving Iran

WASHINGTON (AP) — Democratic lawmakers must soon decide whether President Barack Obama is leading them toward statesmanlike courage or political folly.
Obama used his first State of the Union speech Wednesday to push nervous Democrats to forge ahead on health care, despite voters' worries and opposition from newly strengthened Republicans. Sharpening his focus on the economy, he offered a hodgepodge of tax breaks and other incentives to create new jobs.
For Republicans, Obama blended a mix of overtures and digs. But he mainly addressed fellow Democrats, who still can enact his agenda if they overcome fears fueled by events such as last week's stunning GOP victory in the Massachusetts Senate race.
That setback may have cost Democrats their filibuster-proof Senate majority, Obama said, but "we still have the largest majority in decades, and the people expect us to solve some problems, not run for the hills."
He accepted partial blame for the deep troubles facing his health care push, but he implored lawmakers to finish the task rather than yield to public opposition.

COUNCIL BLUFFS — The Marshalltown Community College baseball team built a nine-run lead and held on to salvage a split against NJCAA Division I No. 12 Iowa Western in Saturday’s Iowa Community College Athletic Conference doubleheader.
MCC won the nightcap 12-10 after Iowa Western claimed the opener 8-4.
The Tigers (19-29, 8-14) scored seven runs in the first inning of game two, sending 13 batters to the plate. The frame was highlighted by a Snayder Ruiz two-run single, and a Kaleb Hanks two-run triple. Ruiz finished game two with three RBIs while Hanks and Diogen Ceballos each drove in two. Jose Mieses, Ceballos and Adam Barrett had two hits apiece, both doubles for Ceballos, as the Tigers rapped out 12 hits in the victory.
The Reivers (40-14, 19-3) got seven runs back between the fourth and fifth innings to pull within two, but MCC came back with three in the sixth. The Tigers needed them all, as Iowa Western plated three in the bottom of the seventh.

Sponsored by Sen. Tom Carper (D-Del.), the Diesel Emissions Reduction Act (DERA) of 2019 would reauthorize the program at the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency through 2024 to assist firms with rebuilding or retrofitting diesel engines. The objective is for those updated engines to be able to comply with pollution standards.
The Environment and Public Works panel advanced the measure to the floor of the Senate by voice vote. Carper, the panel’s ranking Democrat, had initially authored the bill more than a decade ago with former Ohio Sen. George Voinovich (R).
“With today’s vote, we’re one step closer to making sure this bipartisan tradition, imagined and incepted by my dear friend Sen. Voinovich, will continue to boost economic growth and encourage environmental progress,” Carper added. Voinovich died in 2016.
Co-sponsors of the bill include committee Chairman John Barrasso (R-Wyo.), as well as Republican Sens. Graciousness might not seem like the most important thing in defining the success of a nation, but it is paramount for Mr Lim Siong Guan, the Institute of Policy Studies' fourth S R Nathan Fellow for the Study of Singapore.
Having served 37 years in the civil service, five of which as its head, Mr Lim said that based on his experience, there are four words to describe what Singapore needs in order to be a successful and sustainable nation state - "gracious society, Smart Nation".

He was speaking yesterday at the launch of his book, Can Singapore Fall? Making The Future For Singapore, which is a compilation of three lectures he delivered between September and November last year.

Robert E. Gates, 65, Altoona, passed away Friday at UPMC Altoona.
Known as Flip, he was born in Massachusetts, son of the late Patricia Gates. He married Cindy Thompson.
Surviving are his wife; two daughters: Heather Cramer (Laramy) of Coalport and Jessica Gates of Altoona; two sisters: Cheryl McKeen in Florida and Carol Martin of Indiana, Pa.; his mother-in-law, Joan Thompson; an aunt, Sandy Martin in Tennessee; and a granddaughter, Anna Cramer.
Bob served in the U.S. Marine Corps as a lance corporal. He retired from the Altoona Hospital Police Department with 38 years of service and also worked part-time for the Williamsburg Police Department. He was a member of Wehnwood United Methodist Church.

Lynn Blake, left, teaches two hospital employees CPR at the VVMC Safety Fair. Blakeâs passion for educating Eagle County residents came from her own Sudden Cardiac Arrest, which a bystander provided CPR and saved her life. She was just 27 at the time.
On Valentine’s Day 2007, Lynn Blake was embarking on a new job in Vail Village when she had a rude awakening. The 27-year-old suffered sudden cardiac arrest. Fortunately for her, someone trained in CPR stepped forward and kept her heart beating until emergency personnel arrived with a defibrillator. If someone dropped in front of you unconscious, with no notable pulse, would you know what to do? Some 325,000 people die every year of sudden cardiac arrest (SCA) in the United States. And, contrary to popular belief, it strikes people of all ages. “I did not know a thing about cardiac arrest. I didn’t know what it was,” Blake said. Now she knows firsthand about sudden cardiac arrest. The structural budget position is defined as the actual budget deficit (or surplus) less the effects of cyclical deviations of output from potential output. Because of the margin of uncertainty that attaches to estimates of cyclical gaps and to tax and expenditure elasticities with respect to national income, indicators of structural budget positions should be interpreted as broad orders of magnitude.
